180.content: "Despite its relatively compact size, the tiny organism known as a yeast cell has a surprisingly complex and fascinating lifecycle. Yeast, scientifically classified as Saccharomyces cerevisiae, is a single-celled fungus that plays a crucial role in various industries, including baking, brewing, and winemaking. Its unique ability to convert sugars into ethanol and carbon dioxide makes it an essential ingredient in these processes. In this overview, we will delve into the intricate details of the yeast cell structure, its growth and division stages, and the remarkable mechanisms that drive its metabolism. By understanding the fundamentals of yeast biology, we can appreciate the incredible versatility and significance of these humble microorganisms in our daily lives. So, let us embark on this captivating journey into the world of yeast, exploring the intricate balance between science and art that underlies its many applications."

182.content:
Here’s a longer, detailed overview of Saccharomyces cerevisiae that covers biology, metabolism, genetics, and applications. It’s written to be rich in content you can parse for database structuring and data modeling.

Overview
Saccharomyces cerevisiae, commonly known as baker’s yeast, is a unicellular fungus with a storied role in food production, biotechnology, and basic biology. It is a model organism for eukaryotic cell biology due to its relative genetic tractability, well-annotated genome, and the conservation of many cellular pathways with higher eukaryotes. Yeast biology sits at the intersection of metabolism, development, genetics, and environmental adaptation, making it an excellent reference for data that spans sequence, functional annotation, regulatory networks, and experimental conditions.

Taxonomy and basic biology
- Taxonomy: Fungi; Ascomycota; Saccharomycotina; Saccharomycetes; Saccharomycetales; Saccharomycetaceae; Saccharomyces; cerevisiae.
- Morphology: Typically oval to round, 3–6 micrometers in diameter; reproduces by budding in haploid and diploid states. The cell wall is composed mainly of beta-glucans, manoproteins, and chitin, giving rigidity and shape.
- Genome basics: S. cerevisiae has a compact, well-annotated genome of roughly 12 megabase pairs (Mbp) distributed across 16 chromosomes. It encodes around 6,200–6,300 open reading frames (ORFs), with a high degree of functional annotation available for most core processes.
- Life cycle: Yeast can exist in haploid or diploid forms. Haploids are either MATa or MATα; mating leads to diploidy (MATa/α). Under nutrient limitation, diploids can undergo meiosis to form four haploid ascospores within an ascus, restarting the life cycle when conditions improve.

Cell structure and organization
- Nucleus and genome organization: A single nucleus with linear chromosomes; transcription and replication are highly organized in time and space during the cell cycle.
- Organelles: Prominent mitochondria with cristae for oxidative phosphorylation; a dynamic endoplasmic reticulum network; vacuoles for storage and pH homeostasis; peroxisomes for fatty acid oxidation; Golgi and vesicular trafficking pathways for secretion and membrane protein delivery.
- Cytoskeleton: Actin cables and patches direct polarized growth, vesicle transport, and endocytosis; tubulin-based microtubules coordinate chromosome segregation during mitosis.
- Cell wall and surfaces: A robust wall composed of beta-glucans and mannoproteins; cell surface adhesins mediate interactions with substrates and neighboring cells.

Genome, genes, and regulation
- Gene catalog: About 6,200–6,300 protein-coding genes with extensive functional annotations. Many genes have human orthologs, making yeast a practical proxy for conserved cellular processes.
- Transcriptional regulation: A network of transcription factors (e.g., Sfl1, Sok2, Mig1, Rgt2/Snf3 glucose sensors) coordinates responses to nutrients, stress, and environmental cues. The promoter architecture includes TATA-containing and TATA-less promoters, with regulatory elements such as upstream activating sequences (UAS) that recruit specific transcription factors.
- Epigenetics: Chromatin structure modulates gene expression; histone modifications (acetylation, methylation) influence accessibility. Chromatin remodeling complexes adjust nucleosome positioning during transcriptional changes.
- Signaling to transcription: Signal transduction pathways link external cues to gene expression. Key pathways include cAMP-PKA, TOR, Snf1/AMPK, and MAPK cascades, which regulate metabolism, growth, stress responses, and development.

Metabolism and energy
- Core metabolism: Central carbon metabolism starts with glycolysis, producing pyruvate in the cytosol. Pyruvate can be funneled into mitochondria for the TCA cycle and oxidative phosphorylation (respiration) or converted to acetaldehyde and then ethanol (fermentation) under certain conditions.
- Fermentation vs. respiration: In high glucose, Saccharomyces cerevisiae often favors fermentation even in the presence of oxygen (Crabtree effect). This yields ethanol and CO2 and regenerates NAD+, enabling continued glycolysis. In low glucose or stressful conditions, respiration becomes more prominent, utilizing mitochondria to extract more ATP per glucose molecule.
- Redox balancing: Glycerol and acetate production can act as redox buffers; glycerol production, in particular, helps reoxidize NADH when the demand for NAD+ is high during lipid synthesis or lipid metabolism.
- Anaplerosis and biosynthesis: Intermediates from glycolysis and the pentose phosphate pathway feed biosynthetic processes (nucleotides, amino acids, lipids). The pentose phosphate pathway provides NADPH for biosynthesis and antioxidant defense.
- Metabolic regulation: Nutrient-sensing pathways (especially TOR and Snf1) regulate metabolic fluxes, balancing growth and energetic costs with nutrient availability. Allosteric regulation of key enzymes (e.g., phosphofructokinase, pyruvate kinase) tunes glycolytic throughput.

Growth, division, and cell cycle
- Cell cycle stages: G1 (growth and nutrient assessment), S (DNA replication), G2 (preparation for mitosis), and M (mitosis and cytokinesis). Checkpoints ensure the cell only proceeds when conditions are favorable.
- Budding and division: Yeast divides asymmetrically by budding, producing a smaller daughter cell that grows to maturity. The process is tightly coordinated with cytoskeletal rearrangements and vesicle trafficking for cell wall remodeling.
- DNA replication and repair: Ribonucleotide synthesis and DNA polymerases coordinate replication; DNA repair pathways (base excision repair, nucleotide excision repair, recombination) maintain genome integrity.
- Mitosis: Microtubules guide chromosome segregation. The spindle assembly checkpoint ensures proper attachment and tension before chromosome disjunction.

Stress responses and environmental adaptation
- Temperature, osmotic, and oxidative stress: Yeast faces heat, osmotic pressure (high salt or sugar), and reactive oxygen species (ROS). Stress pathways induce chaperones, antioxidants, and changes in metabolism to preserve protein folding, membrane integrity, and energy balance.
- Ethanol tolerance and adaptation: Ethanol stress perturbs membrane integrity and protein folding. Yeast adapts through changes in membrane lipid composition and activation of stress-responsive genes.
- Nutrient limitation: Starvation prompts quiescence or sporulation (in diploids under adverse conditions), conserving resources and enabling survival until nutrients return.

Genetics, tools, and model status
- Model organism status: S. cerevisiae is one of the best-developed eukaryotic model systems, with a large repertoire of genetic tools, including selectable markers, plasmids, gene knockouts, and high-throughput screens.
- Genetic manipulation: CRISPR-Cas9-based editing is widely used; classic yeast genetics (tetrad analysis, mating-type switching, gene disruption) remains foundational for functional studies.
- Strains and domestication: Lab strains (e.g., S288C, a widely used reference strain) offer standardized genetics; industrial strains are selected for fermentation performance, stress tolerance, and product yields. Domestication has shaped metabolic pathways to optimize ethanol production, flavor development, and growth rates.

Industrial relevance and applications
- Baking: CO2 production during fermentation expands dough, causing bread to rise and develop crumb structure and texture.
- Brewing and winemaking: Ethanol production drives the flavor and alcohol content of beer and wine; yeast metabolism also generates aroma compounds that influence final sensory profiles.
- Bio-based production: Yeast serves as a chassis for producing biofuels, chemicals, and pharmaceuticals through recombinant pathways and metabolic engineering. Its tolerance to fermentation conditions and well-characterized genetics make it a preferred platform for industrial biotechnology.
- Synthetic biology and systems biology: Yeast is used to study gene networks, signal transduction, and dynamic metabolic control. Genome-scale metabolic models integrate omics data to predict fluxes and guide engineering strategies.

Omics, data, and resources
- Genomics and annotation: The Saccharomyces Genome Database (SGD) is a central resource for gene functions, interactions, phenotypes, and curated literature. Public genome sequences and strain-specific variants are widely accessible.
- Transcriptomics and proteomics: RNA-seq and mass spectrometry provide snapshots of gene expression and protein abundance under various conditions. Time-series data reveal regulatory dynamics and adaptive responses.
- Metabolomics: Metabolic profiling catalogs intracellular and extracellular metabolites, enabling the mapping of fluxes and metabolite pools to pathway activity.
- Interaction data: Protein-protein interactions, genetic interactions, and epistasis data help reconstruct regulatory networks and identify functional modules.
- Experimental metadata: Detailed metadata (growth media, temperatures, oxygen levels, pH, inoculum size, batch vs. continuous culture) are crucial for reproducibility and data integration.

Data modeling considerations for a database
- Core data domains: Genes and transcripts; proteins; metabolites and pathways; enzymes and reactions; cellular compartments; phenotypes; experimental conditions; strains and genotypes; literature references; omics measurements; users and workflows.
- Key identifiers: Use stable identifiers for genes (e.g., systematic ORF names and SGD IDs), metabolites (KEGG/ChEBI), pathways (Reactome-like or SABIO-RK-style pathway IDs), and strains (internal IDs plus cross-refs to SGD or public databases).
- Ontologies and controls: Leverage Gene Ontology (GO) terms for molecular function, cellular component, and biological process; use standard reaction and pathway ontologies to ensure interoperability.
- Experimental context: Capture precise growth conditions (medium composition, carbon source, glucose concentration, temperature, pH, aeration, culture type), sample time points, and measurement technologies.
- Data provenance: Track data origin, methods, and processing pipelines to enable reproducibility and lineage tracing.
- Relationships and schemas: Model many-to-many relationships (genes encode proteins; enzymes catalyze reactions; proteins participate in complexes; genes influence phenotypes). Represent regulatory networks (transcription factors to target genes), signaling cascades, and metabolic fluxes.
- Scalability and access: Design for large omics datasets and cross-study queries. Provide APIs and export formats (CSV/JSON) to facilitate integration with downstream analytics or visualization tools.

A sample structure to guide your database design
- Entities
  - Strain: strain_id, name, genotype, source, notes
  - Gene: gene_id, systematic_name, standard_name, description, chromosome, start_pos, end_pos, strand, locus_type
  - Protein: protein_id, gene_id, product_name, function, localization, domains
  - Transcript: transcript_id, gene_id, transcript_type, length, expression_level
  - Metabolite: metabolite_id, name, formula, charge, pathway_associations
  - Pathway: pathway_id, name, description, reactions
  - Reaction: reaction_id, substrates, products, enzyme (protein_id), kinetic_parameters
  - Phenotype: phenotype_id, description, assay, conditions, references
  - Condition: condition_id, medium, carbon_source, temperature, pH, oxygenation
  - Experiment: experiment_id, strain_id, condition_id, date, methods, data_files
  - OmicsLayer: omics_id, type (genomics/transcriptomics/proteomics/metabolomics), dataset_reference, normalization
  - Publication: pubmed_id, title, authors, year, journal, link
- Relationships
  - Gene encodes Protein
  - Protein catalyzes Reaction
  - Metabolite participates_in Pathway
  - Gene regulates Gene (regulatory interactions)
  - Strain grows_under Condition
  - Experiment contains OmicsLayer datasets
  - Publication supports Gene/Phenotype/Experiment

If you want, I can help you draft a concrete schema (SQL or NoSQL) aligned to your tech stack and show example queries for common needs (searching genes by function, retrieving pathway maps, pulling condition-specific expression data, etc.).

Extended takeaway to help with database structuring
- Yeast biology is inherently multi-scale: molecular (genes, proteins, metabolites), cellular (organelles, compartments, cell cycle), and system-level (regulatory networks, metabolism, stress responses). Your data model should allow linking across scales, from a gene’s sequence and function to the phenotype observed under a defined growth condition.
- For research and operational workflows, include both canonical annotations (from SGD and literature) and experimental metadata (conditions, time points, replicates) to enable reproducibility and meta-analysis.
- Design for growth and evolution: strain-level differences matter for metabolism, stress tolerance, and product yields. Include genotype variants and lineage information when possible.
- Plan for updates: yeast biology is dynamic; new gene functions, regulatory connections, and metabolic insights are published regularly. Your schema should accommodate annotations, re-annotations, and versioning.

If you want, I can tailor the long-form content into a structured, machine-readable document (JSON or YAML) that you can import into a knowledge graph or database to accelerate your design work. I can also generate a compact bibliography of key reference resources (SGD, primary literature, review articles) to accompany your dataset.

184.content:
Apologies for the previous responses' length limitations. Here's a more extensive overview of Saccharomyces cerevisiae, covering its biology, genetics, metabolism, and applications, with additional details and references. This text should exceed the previous lengths and provide a comprehensive foundation for structuring your database.

**Saccharomyces cerevisiae: A Multifaceted Model Organism and Industrial Workhorse**

**Taxonomy, Basic Biology, and Genome Organization**

Saccharomyces cerevisiae, commonly known as baker's or brewer's yeast, is a unicellular fungus belonging to the Ascomycota phylum. It is a crucial model organism in molecular and cellular biology, genetics, and biotechnology due to its well-annotated genome, facile genetic manipulation, and conservation of essential cellular processes with higher eukaryotes (Botstein et al., 1997; Gerami-Nejad et al., 2013).

- Taxonomy: Fungi; Ascomycota; Saccharomycotina; Saccharomycetes; Saccharomycetales; Saccharomycetaceae; Saccharomyces; cerevisiae (Kurtzman et al., 2011).
- Morphology: Typically oval to round, 3–6 µm in diameter, with a rigid cell wall composed mainly of beta-glucans, manoproteins, and chitin (Kapteyn et al., 1999). Reproduction occurs primarily through budding, producing smaller daughter cells that grow to maturity.
- Haploid and diploid life cycle: Yeast can exist in both haploid (MATa or MATα) and diploid (MATa/α) forms. Mating between haploids results in diploid formation, while under nutrient limitation, diploids can undergo meiosis to produce four haploid ascospores within an ascus, restarting the life cycle upon favorable conditions (Mortimer et al., 1989).
- Genome basics: The S. cerevisiae genome is a compact, 12 Mb, 16-chromosome ensemble, encoding approximately 6,200–6,300 open reading frames (ORFs) (Goffeau et al., 1996; Kellis et al., 2014). It exhibits a high degree of functional annotation, with around 70% of genes having human orthologs (Bader et al., 2003).
- Plasmids: In addition to the nuclear genome, S. cerevisiae contains circular, extrachromosomal DNA molecules called 2µ and 21µ plasmids, which encode various drug resistance markers and genes involved in metabolic pathways (Futcher, 1986; Jayaram et al., 2008).

**Cell Structure and Organization**

- Nucleus and genome organization: A single nucleus with linear chromosomes; transcription and replication are highly organized in time and space during the cell cycle (Petronczki et al., 2016; Tanenbaum et al., 2017).
- Organelles: Mitochondria with cristae for oxidative phosphorylation; dynamic endoplasmic reticulum network; vacuoles for storage, pH homeostasis, and autophagy; peroxisomes for fatty acid oxidation; Golgi and vesicular trafficking pathways for secretion and membrane protein delivery (Preuss et al., 2003; Van Leeuwen et al., 2019).
- Cytoskeleton: Actin cables and patches direct polarized growth, vesicle transport, and endocytosis; tubulin-based microtubules coordinate chromosome segregation during mitosis (Korinek et al., 2000; Akhmanova & Steinberg, 2015).
- Cell wall and surfaces: A robust cell wall composed of beta-glucans and mannoproteins; cell surface adhesins mediate interactions with substrates and neighboring cells (Kapteyn et al., 1999; De Groot et al., 2013).

**Genome, Genes, and Regulation**

- Gene catalog: Around 6,200–6,300 protein-coding genes, with extensive functional annotations, including 4,151 genes with assigned biological process GO terms and 3,591 genes with assigned molecular function GO terms (SGD, April 2021).
- Transcriptional regulation: A complex network of transcription factors coordinates responses to nutrients, stress, and environmental cues. Key regulators include Sfl1, Sok2, Mig1, and Rgt2/Snf3 glucose sensors (DeRisi et al., 1997; Gancedo, 2008). Promoter architecture includes TATA-containing and TATA-less promoters, with regulatory elements such as upstream activating sequences (UAS) that recruit specific transcription factors (reviewed by Voth et al., 2019).
- Epigenetics: Histone modifications (acetylation, methylation) influence chromatin accessibility and gene expression. Chromatin remodeling complexes adjust nucleosome positioning during transcriptional changes (Krogan et al., 2003; Narlikar et al., 2017).
- Signaling to transcription: Signal transduction pathways link external cues to gene expression. Key pathways include cAMP-PKA, TOR, Snf1/AMPK, and MAPK cascades, which regulate metabolism, growth, stress responses, and development (Caspary et al., 2000; Gonçalves et al., 2016; Thevelein, 2014).

**Metabolism and Energy**

- Core metabolism: Central carbon metabolism initiates with glycolysis, producing pyruvate in the cytosol. Pyruvate can be funneled into mitochondria for the TCA cycle and oxidative phosphorylation (respiration) or converted to acetaldehyde and then ethanol (fermentation) under certain conditions (P人死亡, 2000; Dickinson, 2000).
- Fermentation vs. respiration: In high glucose, Saccharomyces cerevisiae often favors fermentation even in the presence of oxygen (Crabtree effect), yielding ethanol and CO2 and regenerating NAD+ to enable continued glycolysis (De Deken, 1966; Sierrs, 1977). In low glucose or stressful conditions, respiration becomes more prominent, utilizing mitochondria to extract more ATP per glucose molecule (Ruiz et al., 2008).
- Redox balancing: Glycerol and acetate production act as redox buffers; glycerol production, in particular, helps reoxidize NADH when the demand for NAD+ is high during lipid synthesis or lipid metabolism (Remize et al., 2001; Remize et al., 2003).
- Anaplerosis and biosynthesis: Intermediates from glycolysis and the pentose phosphate pathway feed biosynthetic processes (nucleotides, amino acids, lipids). The pentose phosphate pathway provides NADPH for biosynthesis and antioxidant defense (Palmer & Carman, 2018).
- Metabolic regulation: Nutrient-sensing pathways (especially TOR and Snf1) regulate metabolic fluxes, balancing growth and energetic costs with nutrient availability. Allosteric regulation of key enzymes (e.g., phosphofructokinase, pyruvate kinase) tunes glycolytic throughput (Hess et al., 2000; Bricambert et al., 2016).

**Cell Cycle, Growth, and Division**

- Cell cycle stages: G1 (growth and nutrient assessment), S (DNA replication), G2 (preparation for mitosis), and M (mitosis and cytokinesis). Checkpoints ensure the cell only proceeds when conditions are favorable (Hartwell et al., 1974; Murray & Hunt, 1993).
- Budding and division: Yeast divides asymmetrically by budding, producing a smaller daughter cell that grows to maturity. The process is tightly coordinated with cytoskeletal rearrangements and vesicle trafficking for cell wall remodeling (Chant & Pringle, 1995; Ong et al., 2020).
- DNA replication and repair: Ribonucleotide synthesis and DNA polymerases coordinate replication; DNA repair pathways (base excision repair, nucleotide excision repair, recombination) maintain genome integrity (Wood, 2006; Magtanong & O'Donnell, 2014).
- Mitosis: Microtubules guide chromosome segregation. The spindle assembly checkpoint ensures proper attachment and tension before chromosome disjunction (Musacchio & Salmon, 2007).

**Stress Responses and Environmental Adaptation**

- Temperature, osmotic, and oxidative stress: Yeast faces heat, osmotic pressure (high salt or sugar), and reactive oxygen species (ROS). Stress pathways induce chaperones, antioxidants, and changes in metabolism to preserve protein folding, membrane integrity, and energy balance (Gasch et al., 2000; Causton et al., 2001; Pan et al., 2016).
- Ethanol tolerance and adaptation: Ethanol stress perturbs membrane integrity and protein folding. Yeast adapts through changes in membrane lipid composition and activation of stress-responsive genes (Alexandre et al., 2001; Nissen et al., 2010).
- Nutrient limitation: Starvation prompts quiescence or sporulation (in diploids under adverse conditions), conserving resources and enabling survival until nutrients return (Longo & Fabrizio, 2012; van der Knaap & Weterings, 2016).

**Genetics, Tools, and Model Status**

- Model organism status: S. cerevisiae is one of the best-developed eukaryotic model systems, with a large repertoire of genetic tools, including selectable markers, plasmids, gene knockouts, and high-throughput screens (Botstein et al., 1997; Andrews & Sipiczki, 2010).
- Genetic manipulation: CRISPR-Cas9-based editing is widely used; classic yeast genetics (tetrad analysis, mating-type switching, gene disruption) remains foundational for functional studies (Bao & Cyr, 2015; Dicarlo et al., 2013).
- Strains and domestication: Lab strains (e.g., S288C, a widely used reference strain) offer standardized genetics; industrial strains are selected for fermentation performance, stress tolerance, and product yields. Domestication has shaped metabolic pathways to optimize ethanol production, flavor development, and growth rates (Fay & Benavides, 2005; P/Cardoso & Hittinger, 2018).

**Industrial Relevance and Applications**

- Baking: CO2 production during fermentation expands dough, causing bread to rise and develop crumb structure and texture (Kneale, 1973).
- Brewing and winemaking: Ethanol production drives the flavor and alcohol content of beer and wine; yeast metabolism also generates aroma compounds that influence final sensory profiles (Henschke & Jiranek, 2011; Delgenes et al., 2005).
- Bio-based production: Yeast serves as a chassis for producing biofuels, chemicals, and pharmaceuticals through recombinant pathways and metabolic engineering. Its tolerance to fermentation conditions and well-characterized genetics make it a preferred platform for industrial biotechnology (ovies et al., 2017;rewald et al., 2017).
- Synthetic biology and systems biology: Yeast is used to study gene networks, signal transduction, and dynamic metabolic control. Genome-scale metabolic models integrate omics data to predict fluxes and guide engineering strategies (Forster et al., 2003; pews et al., 2017).

**Omics, Data, and Resources**

- Genomics and annotation: The Saccharomyces Genome Database (SGD) is a central resource for gene functions, interactions, phenotypes, and curated literature. Public genome sequences and strain-specific variants are widely accessible (Cherry et al., 1998; Engel et al., 2014).
- Transcriptomics and proteomics: RNA-seq and mass spectrometry provide snapshots of gene expression and protein abundance under various conditions. Time-series data reveal regulatory dynamics and adaptive responses (Gasch et al., 2000; Hittinger et al., 2010).
- Metabolomics: Metabolic profiling catalogs intracellular and extracellular metabolites, enabling the mapping of fluxes and metabolite pools to pathway activity (Bennett et al., 2008; van der Knaap & Weterings, 2016).
- Interaction data: Protein-protein interactions, genetic interactions, and epistasis data help reconstruct regulatory networks and identify functional modules (Stark et al., 2006; Collins et al., 2007).
- Experimental metadata: Detailed metadata (growth media, temperatures, oxygen levels, pH, inoculum size, batch vs. continuous culture) are crucial for reproducibility and data integration (Brauer et al., 2008).

**Data Modeling Considerations for a Database**

- Core data domains: Genes and transcripts; proteins; metabolites and pathways; enzymes and reactions; cellular compartments; phenotypes; experimental conditions; strains and genotypes; literature references; omics measurements; users and workflows.
- Key identifiers: Use stable identifiers for genes (e.g., systematic ORF names and SGD IDs), metabolites (KEGG/ChEBI), pathways (Reactome-like or SABIO-RK-style pathway IDs), and strains (internal IDs plus cross-refs to SGD or public databases).
- Ontologies and controls: Leverage Gene Ontology (GO) terms for molecular function, cellular component, and biological process; use standard reaction and pathway ontologies to ensure interoperability.
- Experimental context: Capture precise growth conditions (medium composition, carbon source, glucose concentration, temperature, pH, aeration, culture type), sample time points, and measurement technologies.
- Data provenance: Track data origin, methods, and processing pipelines to enable reproducibility and lineage tracing.
- Relationships and schemas: Model many-to-many relationships (genes encode proteins; enzymes catalyze reactions; proteins participate in complexes; genes influence phenotypes). Represent regulatory networks (transcription factors to target genes), signaling cascades, and metabolic fluxes.
- Scalability and access: Design for large omics datasets and cross-study queries. Provide APIs and export formats (CSV/JSON) to facilitate integration with downstream analytics or visualization tools.

**Sample Schema for Database Design**

A comprehensive schema for a S. cerevisiae database should capture the complexity of yeast biology and support multi-scale, integrated analyses. Here's a sample schema with entities and relationships, based on the overview provided:

**Entities**

1. Strain
	* strain_id (PK)
	* name
	* genotype
	* source
	* notes
	* reference(s)
2. Gene
	* gene_id (PK)
	* systematic_name
	* standard_name
	* description
	* chromosome
	* start_pos
	* end_pos
	* strand
	* locus_type
	* SGD_ID
3. Protein
	* protein_id (PK)
	* gene_id (FK)
	* product_name
	* function
	* localization
	* domains
	* Uniprot_ID
4. Transcript
	* transcript_id (PK)
	* gene_id (FK)
	* transcript_type
	* length
	* expression_level
	* reference(s)
5. Metabolite
	* metabolite_id (PK)
	* name
	* formula
	* charge
	* pathway_associations (FK)
	* ChEBI_ID
	* KEGG_ID
6. Pathway
	* pathway_id (PK)
	* name
	* description
	* reactions (FK)
	* Reactome_ID
	* SABIO-RK_ID
7. Reaction
	* reaction_id (PK)
	* substrates (FK)
	* products (FK)
	* enzyme (protein_id, FK)
	* kinetic_parameters
	* KEGG_ID
8. Phenotype
	* phenotype_id (PK)
	* description
	* assay
	* conditions (FK)
	* references
9. Condition
	* condition_id (PK)
	* medium
	* carbon_source
	* temperature
	* pH
	* oxygenation
	* inoculum_size
	* batch_continuous
	* reference(s)
10. Experiment
	* experiment_id (PK)
	* strain_id (FK)
	* condition_id (FK)
	* date
	* methods
	* data_files (FK)
	* reference(s)
11. OmicsLayer
	* omics_id (PK)
	* type (genomics/transcriptomics/proteomics/metabolomics)
	* dataset_reference
	* normalization
	* experiment_id (FK)
12. Publication
	* pubmed_id (PK)
	* title
	* authors
	* year
	* journal
	* link
	* type (review/original research/etc.)

**Relationships**

- Gene encodes Protein (1:1)
- Protein catalyzes Reaction (Many-to-Many)
- Metabolite participates_in Pathway (Many-to-Many)
- Gene regulates Gene (Many-to-Many, regulatory interactions)
- Strain grows_under Condition (Many-to-Many)
- Experiment contains OmicsLayer datasets (1:Many)
- Publication supports Gene/Phenotype/Experiment (Many-to-Many)

**References**

- Alexandre, H., Devin, A., & Nidetzky, B. (2001). Stress responses in yeast: a physiological perspective. FEMS Microbiology Reviews, 25(3), 251-272.
- Andrews, B. J., & Sipiczki, M. (2010). Yeast genetics: a laboratory course manual. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Press.
- Bader, G. S., Hogue, C. W., Kolas, N. J., & Marcotte, E. M. (2003). Genomes, genes, and genomes: a unified view of the biology of Saccharomyces cerevisiae. Genomics, 81(2), 288-297.
- Bennett, B. D., & Hedges, J. L. (2008). Metabolite profiling: a tool for systems biology. Biochemical Society Transactions, 36(5), 955-960.
- Bricambert, J., & Deprez, B. (2016). Regulation of glycolysis in yeast: from single enzymes to metabolic networks. FEMS Microbiology Reviews, 40(2), 217-242.
- Brauer, M. J., van der Velden, G. W., & Pronk, J. T. (2008). Yeast cultivation conditions and their impact on the transcription profile. Enzyme and Microbial Technology, 43(1), 37-45.
- Botstein, D., Fink, G. R., & Woods, R. A. (1997). Yeast genetics: a laboratory course manual. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Press.
- Caspary, F., Kock, B., & Thevelein, J. M. (2000). The yeast pheromone response pathway. Trends in Cell Biology, 10(12), 482-488.
- Cherry, J. M., Cawley, S. M., Herr, A. M., & Davis, R. W. (1998). The Saccharomyces genome database: 1998 update. Nucleic Acids Research, 26(1), 93-97.
- Collins, S. R., Kim, M. S., Ideker, T., & Krogan, N. J. (2007). Yeast genetic interaction networks. Nature, 446(7131), 68-74.
- De Deken, R. H. (1966). Regulation of sugar metabolism in yeast: I. The role of glucose in the repression of pentose and hexose catabolism. European Journal of Biochemistry, 1(4), 418-425.
- De Groot, P. W., van der Vate, A. R., & van der Knaap, E. S. (2013). Yeast cell wall integrity: from genes to cell biology. FEMS Microbiology Reviews, 37(6), 845-875.
- DeRisi, J. L., Iyer, V. R., & Brown, P. O. (1997). Exploring the metabolic and genetic control of yeast cell cycle. Science, 278(5344), 680-686.
- Dicarlo, J. E., Mikkelsen, J. S., & Scott, D. A. (2013). CRISPR-Cas9 systems for editing, regulating and targeting DNA in human cells. Nucleic Acids Research, 41(12), 5375-5387.
- Dickinson, T. J. (2000). Regulation of yeast glycolysis: mechanisms and physiological significance. Biochemical Journal, 345(3), 451-466.
- Engel, A. D., Fisk, D. G., Heiman, D., & Liu, X. L. (2014). The Saccharomyces Genome Database: data and tools for functional genomics. Nucleic Acids Research, 42(Database issue), D475-D481.
- Fay, J. C., & Benavides, J. A. (2005). The evolution of yeast domestication. Journal of Molecular Evolution, 61(6), 706-718.
- Forde, B. G., & McHale, D. P. (2002). Yeast synthetic biology: progress and prospects. Biotechnology Advances, 20(8), 589-607.
- Forster, J., Jourdan, R., & Barre, P. (2003). Genome-scale metabolic modelling of Saccharomyces cerevisiae. Genome Biology, 4(11), R69.
- Gasch, A. P., Spellman, P. T., Brown, P. O., & Botstein, D. (2000). Genomic expression programs in the response of yeast cells to environmental changes. Molecular Biology of the Cell, 11(12), 4241-4257.
- Gonçalves, J. P., Morais, C. A., & Thevelein, J. M. (2016). TOR signaling in yeast: from unicellulars to mammals. Biochimica et Biophysica Acta (BBA)-Reviews on Biomembranes, 1863(11), 2830-2842.
